reviewText: You'll realize how far the Online FPS genre has fallen in its pursuit of the lowest common denominator when you play this 20 year old game and it shows you things you've never seen before, game types you've never heard of, and speed that will humble you.\n\nPlaying Quake, you begin to see that modern online shooters have leveling systems and gear grinds because most players are already experts when they play their first game. The grind is a way to keep people playing when they have no other reason to play. Quake doesn't need the grind because the progression happens with you instead of your gear: You need to actually practice to get better at this game. And that is a lot more fun than grinding to unlock the next gun in some gear tree.
voteText: 2,634 of 2,803 people (94%) found this review helpful 12 people found this review funny

reviewText: The only online shooter that doesn't let you make excuses. If you die, it's because the other guy was better. He wasn't using OP weapons or perks, he wasn't camping the same cheesy spot half the game, he wasn't 20 levels higher than you. He controlled the map better, watched the timer for important pickups more closely, strafed better, or aimed better. He was just ♥♥♥♥ing better, and Quake gives you no choice but to suck it up and learn what not to do.

reviewText:
Recommended.

Older gamers that didn't know Quake was still played today, rejoice.
Younger gamers that may want to try their hands at something difficult yet fun, welcome. We need you blood; come and quench our thirst. Well, actually, the way Quake Live is made, chances are new players will get to play between themselves and mid-skilled players mostly so I guess I'll have to wait for you to escalate the skill cliff. But please do so!

So what is Quake Live? Some might say this is a Free To Play version of Quake 3 Arena. There is some truth to that and this is how QL was identified since its inception yet there is more to it. Q3A had mods, QL tries to incorporate them into the main game instead. Q3A had a large community running plenty of servers, QL has servers ran exclusively by id software with the option for subscribers to spawn their own customized using this infrastructure. Q3A had a one time payment, QL generates its revenues through a subscription system. It's worth noting that despite being Free To Play, QL is not Pay To Win (and it's a shame that both expressions have almost become synonymous today).

You might still wonder why you should play QL if you have Q3A. Well the main argument is kinda lame but I'm afraid it is true nonetheless : QL is overwhelmingly more populated than any other Quake at the moment. But there are reasons for that! For starters, it's easy to get into. You press the install" button
recommended: you create your account then you click on "Play Now" and you're set. You won't be told you don't have the right mod installed or you lack a specific version of a map. It's easy (but you can still spend some time tweaking your config if you want to). The same argument can be made about the default gameplay itself and this is where things get somewhat controversial. Purists say the recent changes made to make the game more welcoming to newcomers are a travesty. While I agree that the new default settings are inferior for us experienced players
hoursPlayed: I'm still open to the idea that new players will have it easier and have more fun that way. You can be sure I will still be there in the servers running the classic settings
voteText: waiting for the courageous survivors who defied the default ruleset and want some more. In any case

reviewText:
The people giving this negative reviews are mostly veterans who didn't pay attention to anything SyncError and sponge have been saying for the past year. Here are some facts:

1) They have been telling us to switch to Steam for over a year. The people who already had the game on Steam didn't have to pay a single cent, even if they weren't subscribers. The subscribers who didn't switch even though they were told to do so can mail support and get the game for free.

2) The friends lists weren't saved because the accounts no longer exist. Just find your friends in-game and send them a friend request. We can do that in-game now through the Admin menu, something we couldn't do before.

3) The game works on Linux with Wine/playonlinux.

4) We have user-owned private servers and LAN now, something the fanbase has been begging for since the private Beta.

5) We still have stats. Just not the stats from before the switch, as again, the accounts no longer exist.

6) We can switch names now.

7) Delicious, delicious UTF-8 support finally lets us use Unicode letters in chat.

8) People are working on a replacement for QLRanks.

9) The one-time payment is about a 3rd of the price of a premium/pro account, and everyone can do everything the premium/pro users could.

10) We now have Valve Anti-Cheat. Cheaters who get banned now have to pay money for a new account.

11) The new UI and settings menu are far, far better than the old ones.

12) Watching demos is no longer a pain without 3rd party tools. We can now view our demos by pressing Replays"
date: there is a list of timestamps for each frag that happened in the game
recommended:
and the new demo viewer itself is all kinds of awesome.

13) SyncError confirmed that we'll be getting gibs DLC.

The update was great. Stop whining.


UPDATE: QLRanks is now replaced with QLStats
hoursPlayed: which uses Glicko instead of TrueSkill for team-games
voteText: though in-game it is still called Elo. The difference between Glicko and TrueSkill is that Glicko is based on score per minute instead of wins. Duel still uses plain old Elo.\n\nAlso
helpfulPercent: a bunch of old OSP/CPMA/RA3 content is being brought in via Steam Workshop
votesHelpful: so you will see a number of old maps with letter/number combinations instead of names being voted on various servers."

reviewText:
Over the past 6 years I've spent more time playing QL than any other game which comes out to an absurd amount of hours in-game. I'll do my best to summarize the experience and why you should definitely consider getting into it.

A few things you should know before you get into Quake:

1) This game is the most difficult FPS you will ever play. The core mechanics are easy to understand and it's simple enough to grab a weapon and start shooting so the mantra easy to learn
hoursPlayed: The skill ceiling is so high that no matter how many years you pour into it
voteText: you'll never hit it. This quality makes Quake very daunting for core FPS audiences. Many of the pro tricks take months of practice in order to pull off at just an elementary level.\n\n2) Even if you're really good
helpfulPercent: You're going to lose. A lot. Quake doesn't have an artificially level playing field like most modern games. Quick deaths and large spread fire hitscan weapons do not exist in the same fashion as Battlefield
votesHelpful: COD
votesTotal: or just about any modern FPS series. If you are worse than the player you're up against you are going to lose. People who want undeserved wins or prefer the casual experience aren't going to feel comfortable in Quake Live. The people that play have stuck with it with aggressive loyalty because they have the mind-set of someone who enjoys learning something no matter how hard it is. You play because you can appreciate the skill that it takes to be good. In this way
votesFunny: losing in Quake is actually fun
commentsCount: in so far that you can appreciate the player's skill that you lost to.\n\n3) Even with the recent modernization update
column16: the game lacks certain casual nicities that gamers have become accustomed to. A list of some mechanics QL is missing: Regenerating Health
column20: Standing still to limit weapon spread
column21: Low speed cap on player movement
column23:
Loss of velocity while jumping. These mechanics have become coliquially synonymous with the "tactical" FPS. You'll find that the removal of these features actually promotes tactics a lot more than what you get from the Counter Strike or COD formula.

What is Quake about?

Item timing
column30:
and Rockets everywhere.

Who will enjoy Quake Live?

Gamers that are okay with losing and can respect the reasons that they lost. Gamers that find it enjoyable to learn how the physics engine in their game works and how to take advantage of it. Gamers that don't like frags being handed to them because of a lucky shot.

If you spend the time to get familiar with Quake you'll find that it's the most rewarding experience there is in the FPS genre. When you first pull off the Bridge to Rail jump in Campgrounds you'll shriek with delight. When you win your first duel you'll giddily tell people who could care less about games about it. The better you get the more accomplished you feel and there is no end to how good of a player you can be. The pros are bested all the time by some new blood with ungodly talent and dedication.

If you put in the hours you'll also find one of the most loyal and dedicated communities that there are in gaming. There's sure to be an influx of typical gamer culture trolls in the first few weeks but the people that have stuck it out with Quake
column32: are some of the most level-headed and respectful people out there.\n\nGLHF."

reviewText:
I love Quake but this is a Negative Review on the Overall Quakelive Experience coming from a Veteran player since release of the Quake Series.

The Engine and Game is primarily Quake 3 with some minor and major changes.

The minor changes are the structure of the game menu. No longer do you enter a full screen started menu for Quake. It is now a social window that allows you to browse for games, add and chat with friends, make and add people to clans and is basically just CHAT & Choose your game.

Getting into game from this new design is easy and quick.

There are more modes now like Red Rover and Freeze tag as well as many others.

So it's basically a ramped up Quake 3 with More Modes and Team Arena Weapons are included. There is now a HMG too.

The game usually works smoothly and only the Veterans can sense small issues in weapon hit registration if there are any server hicups.

This game craps on noobs. It also puts lower players in servers that better players cannot join. This is fair enough bit it divides the already small community. And putting the noobs and vets together wouldn't work either due to the sheer high learning curve of the movement and weapon mechanics.

In one way, Quakelive was a step forward from Quake 3... In other ways it is a HUGE step back. No custom maps are allowed... Only the maps that Quakelive Choose to host. You don't actually host your own server, you're using their servers so people who aren't in perth or sydney or adelaide get the highest pings. Most people who connect from Australia to New Zealand get huge pings... But when they connect from New Zealand to Australia they get lower pings than what we get to their servers.

You cannot choose any custom maps and Quakelive are so slow at introducing maps... Especially the blatantly obviously missing maps from RA3 that they slowly feed to us with a drip.

After a while quakelive stagnates and feels like groundhog day. It's bad enough the game being run on Quakelive Engine... But the engine causes FPS problems even with decent cards. You'll need to have a very good card to play even a basic game.

My GTX 770 ran it fine but my 9800GT won't run it smoothly on large maps or even some small maps with weird lighting".  However I used even less than a 9800GT to play Quake 3 smoothly... Go Figure??

Hosting your own games is great... You can edit weapon variables in the Create Server Menu that allow you to change weapon firing rate
recommended: projectile speeds and even accelleration of rockets and plasma and even movement physics can be altered hugely. Add weapon vampirism and Headshots as well as a plethora of settings to allow you to create a game or mod that is completely unique. However
hoursPlayed: if you want to change small things you have to kill the server and then change the settings
voteText:
restart the server again... These changes should be allowed to be modified while the server is running to allow for a more streamlined mod creation experience............

...............That is when you run into the server not shutting down locking you out of re-creating the server.... Then no response from E-Mail support.... Read on about this:

The service provided by ID and/or Bethesda is absolutely shocking.

Good luck getting an E-Mail response even if you pay for Pro subscription (Which provides you access to full E-Mail Support as well as creating servers and Clans)

reviewText:
No fancy crap, just action. Good action.

I hate FPS, and i'm terrible at them, but this is really good. Fast, no connection issues, no complicated setup or registration (just email & nickname and you're good), no endless load times, no constant incentives to buy crap. Nothing is in the game that doesnt belong there.

It's truly free. Pay subscriptions allow you to host matches or sort out your team/clan stuff, so if you're a heavy player you will probably like it, but if all you want is 30 minutes or an hour of killing you don't need to spend any money. Models and railgun color are free as well... so no pay-to-win at all.

The menu interface does look a bit like a crappy browser, but who cares about menus. The detailed info you can browse is good and you can oogle your stats in detail.

Once the match starts it's all about your quick wits, aim and experience. This game is good, and if you're not sure, the download is ~700 Mb and costs nothing to see for yourself.

reviewText:
If you're new to Quake, this is a good place to start. Just be aware that this is without a doubt the worst incantation of the game. I started initially with Quake Live back in 2009. The supply of duelers wasn't great, but skill levels were on an order of magnitude closer than what you'll get in just about any other title in the series. This makes for a great introduction to the intensity and fun of one on one combat, but the duel scene eventually subsided in NA and disappeared entirely over the course of two years. For the better part of three years this game has been dead in everything except Clan Arena which you'll quickly find players get very egotistical over what is essentially Quake with two thirds of the gameplay removed.

The pricing model for this game is one of the worst I've ever seen as you're essentially paying for basic things like voting in maps, playing classic modes, playing with mods, playing more maps, and playing different gametypes. These are all things which are basic in other FPS games which have been restricted to allow iD to suck as much money out of the community as possible. This money does not go to improving the game, as evidenced by the continued ignorance of community input about features and additions they'd like to see done to the game being ignored for years now by the largely incompetent development duo.

In effect this model also killed the duel scene as you could no longer enjoy the 8-10 maps tried and tested to be good for duels (the ones run in tournaments) and instead forcing you into the vast number of amateur and terrible maps which have no place in duel servers and not allowing you to vote for anything unless you pay.

The mod community is also non-existent due to having to subscribe to have your servers hosted at the horrible iD rented server farms and inability of adding any custom settings or maps beyond typical command line tweaking.

I don't expect this game to hold a critical mass for much longer than a month or two, but if this game is fun for you I'd advise you to check out some of the free alternatives such as:

Warsow
Xonotic
QuakeWorld (Quake 1)
CPMA (Quake 3)

These games all have low player counts and may require you to operate IRC, but they're still played today and well worth the effort to get into as they love teaching new players.

If these games are too old or dead for you, continue to play Quake Live for however long it has left and consider playing something like Reflex when it's released.

reviewText:
Long story short: The shift to a pay up-front model has currently got the community in a stir, but to those who haven't yet bought it, Quake Live is a direct update of one of the finest shooters of all time, and this $10 package gives you so much content that it's hard not to recommend to anyone.
Quake III is a classic game. It's simplified the weapon roster from previous Quake games, and refined movement systems and map design, and it was an instant hit. Every weapon had its advantages and disadvantages, and it was easy enough to pick up and play without ruining the competitive scene too.

Quake Live, when it first came out in 2009, basically took that and re-tweaked some of the damage output for the meta, changed the UI, and stuck the Quake Live logo in every level. The original Free-2-Play model worked well for it; several dozen maps were available for free, and anyone can play them, but for $4 a month, players can access nearly four times as many maps, have access to several game modes, and can have set up clan systems.

A few things had changed before the big jump. Bethesda had bought Id in that time, and updates to Quake Live were on the weird side. The game originally was an in-browser game, and it had then been migrated to Steam, but still retaining the web UI on the main menu. Players could also join premium servers and play alongside pro players, but they couldn't host it themselves.

On the 27th of October 2015, Bethesda announced that the game had now completely migrated to Steam. The UI is much better, the game now uses Steam profiles directly, and has Valve Anti-Cheat incorporated. They also got rid of the premium model, so now everyone can do everything in the game. And finally, Steamworks integration now allows 16 years of map making history to be shared and developed easily across the community.

Everyone is peeved though that Bethesda never mentioned anywhere that the game would now not be a Free-2-Play game. It now costs $10 to those who had never played it before. Yes, that is a bit of shoddy business practice, but it doesn't ruin the game in any way. In fact, I think it improves it. Rather than paying $4 a month, the $10 up front gets you full access to all the content all the time. And there's definitely more than 2 and a half months worth of content up for grabs. There's nearly 150 maps in deathmatch alone, and Steam Workshop support keeps upping that number with quality and interesting maps.

The rest of this review is more an evaluation of the game itself.

Quake Live has about 15 weapons on offer, and all of them have their strengths and weaknesses. Like any classic Id game, they're designed to be superior in different map scenarios, and maps are designed in a way to showcase all of them. My favourites are the plasma gun which fires slower moving huge balls of plasma, dishing up massive damage per hit, but it's tricky damaging people from a distance. The rocket launcher is a classic weapon with its large-ish splash radius, and the ability to do rocket jumps everywhere.

Players also move around very quickly, which encourages skillful aiming and finesse with timing weapon shots. There's a lot of emphasis on moving fast and trying to outsmart your opponent while landing hits of your own. Rocket jumps are easy to execute, and provide a risky outtage to any fight, encouraging learning map layouts, hotzones, and power-up locations.

And it all comes together really nicely. Fight for a bit, try to restock on supplies, and then find another fight. Dying is a quick second break until you get thrown back in. Every game mode revolves around this simple draw the enemy concept. Maps aren't huge, so it's never difficult to find some action.

Quake III is a bit of an old game, so the visuals are a little here and there. Particle and lighting effects are still quite well done, and new textures on maps keep a good amount of visual variety. The model detail is a little lacking in some cases, but the overall level of visual fidelity is quite low, which means you can run this game on almost any computer you own.

Sound design is also a bit here and there. The music shows its age a little bit, and isn't available on every map, which leaves a bit of an awkward silence. Weapons make some pretty characteristic sound effects though, and it's always satisfying to hear that little blip sound every time you deal damage to an enemy. The new main menu music they added in the recent update sounds exactly like the menu music from Doom 3 BFG, and it just seems out of place, especially since all demonic imagery from Quake 3 was removed.

Don't be deterred if you see negative reviews or posts about this game though. It runs flawlessly on any hardware from the past ten years, it's fun, fast, frantic, and is ridiculously easy for both new and pro players to play together. With a bazillion maps and game modes on offer, a great community, and lots more free updates coming along, Quake Live is an excellent game that everyone should try out, even if you're not a big FPS fan.

RATING: 3 UP, 0 DOWNMy up/down rating system tries to differentiate between games that are mediocre (less ups and downs total), and games that are interesting but flawed (more ups and downs totals). Ups relate to how much good a game has, and downs are how much bad a game has.

0 UPs        1 UPs        2 UPs        3 UPs                Not worth playing, skip it        Alright, play it if you're into the genre        Very good, play it if you're looking for something worth trying        One to go down in history, a must have for everyone
0 DOWNs        1 DOWNs        2 DOWNs        3 DOWNs                Nothing detrimental in the game        A few things wrong, but doesn't ruin it        Kind-of broken or aggravating, you may not be able to put up with it        Very, very broken, a lesson on what not to do

reviewText:
My personal thoughts on Quake Live.

Prepare for the most adrenaline filled experience ever. Quake 3(live) is a FPS game released originaly in 1999 by iD software, and it's one of the pioneers of the e-sports scene. This game is one of the most hardcore experiences ever, with a large arsenal of weapons and various other power ups, you find yourself battling across multiple arenas and in multiple game modes that are fun and just as intense. Quake live has so much to ofer in a generation of modern military coridor shooters, I don't even know where to start. Any game you start, be it a TDM, CTF or pure Deathmatch is such an adrenaline rush, it makes you think this game was made on cocaine. The sheer speed and precision needed in Quake is unmatched by any shooter out there. With fast respawn/kills, and a new upgraded loadout system, it makes a perfect blend between the Arena shooter and a fair and ballanced FPS game. Dedicated servers work just fine, tight responsive controls, this is a must try. And it's free also, so you have nothing to lose here. If you never tried Quake, you will find yourself in a easy to learn - hard to master game that will provide you with plenty of content to burn out hunders and hundreds of people and hours in this absolute classic. A must own/try .

The best:
Tight responsive controls
Professional shooter
One of the best shooters ever released
Kick-♥♥♥ weapons and maps
Ballanced gameplay mechanics
Easy to learn - hard to master
Dedicated servers and great community (Quake players are mature people who grew up with hardcore shooters in the 90')
Free to play, no paywalls, no special items to buy"
Loadout system ballances the ARENA metagame and makes respawning fair for everyone
Hundreds of maps
date: a couple of multiplayer mods to ensure hundreds of hours of content\nNo regenerating health

reviewText:
Quake is a game of hard skill thresholds. Once a player has reached certain 'checkpoints' in development it becomes very hard, if not impossible, for a player of lower skill to beat this person. Progressing in Quake is a game of losses. Learning how to lose is key. This is of course difficult in a tournament setting, although certain thresholds will be quicker to be overcome as there is a tremendous amount of competitive pressure to do so. The low skilled devour the lower skilled. Sometimes a glimmer of hope, but it is not to be.

reviewText:
tl;dr: AHHAHAHAHAHA $10 YEAH OK

The game is still the same as before, though a bit more polished - the UI feels like it's no longer from 2010 in terms of usability and visuals, and the new Steam Workshop integration is pretty handy to say the least. It just feels better.

It's still Quake Live though, and while you get it for free if you've ever played it before on Steam, it's still a scumbag move to make a game from 1999 cost $10 when it has been available for free for quite many years now, and without notification. That being said, I won't recommend it.

Better spend your hard-earned money somewhere else - this company doesn't deserve it.

reviewText:
Back when Quake Live was first launched to unsuspecting FPS maniacs, community of not-so-pro lovers of Quake fragging was pretty happy. Game was there for free with certain limitations that you could remove via paid subscription. I didn't expect game would be coming to Steam, and when it finally did, I've launched it, all anxious and eager to play. However...

Quake Live via Steam is the first ever Pay-To-Free-To-Play game. The concept is pretty radical - you get a game for free, but for EVERYTHING ELSE you have to pay. I can pinch an idea: make key bindings customizable for 2,99 monthly subscription!

While I can somehow understand the concept of Quake Live on its own website, releasing a product with so many limitations and asking for 35 bucks per year for decade+ old game just to unlock basic stuff such as  creating your own game is completely senseless. Steam is friends-based social network and gaming store and I could understand ZeniMax working to squezze some wallet juice by implementing new cosmetics or via totally, TOTALLY cheap DLC's, but this? This is outrageous and I'm basing this opinion of mine on the fact you can get Quake III Arena for 19 € or even with -75% discounts during sales. Regularly.

Plus... silly and never before seen (for a good reason!) weapon loadouts, server caps for free players... it's downright arrogant.

Now... who do you think gamers are? ♥♥♥♥ing idiots? I mean, are we? I certainly AM NOT.

reviewText:
[quickdisclaimer: New players - seriously if you have the patience, get through these 20 test matches as quickly as possible to play with peopleon your level. Quake Live is putting newcomers with 3rd tier players to ensure that noone will make a new account to bash new players like dust.]

The only multiplayer FPS game that got me hooked for longer than 2 hours. Seriously.

It's a game about improving yourself, your reactions, your reflexes and your tactical thinking. Where might he be next, is he going to take this route to collect this item, or is he going to take another one to capture me at this particular doorway where he might have an advantage? Which weapon should I use, which am i more comfortable with, am I going to do long range sniping or short range rocketing at the moment? The weapons are precise but they REQUIRE serious skills to unlock their true potential.

It's very demanding, but extremely rewarding. The sheer joy after having a good, balanced match is more than enough to keep me hooked.

reviewText:
Latest Patch has changed the game significantly to appeal to more players. From the notes, there's no way I can't say ignore this game now and go back to cpma Q3.

After trying out the standalone again though, I'm glad that CA and Duel have 95% been untouched.

New heavy machinegun : Completely replaces the standard MG.
Auto hop : cg_autohop 0. You don't need this active, in fact it will mess up your stair timings and give you unwanted results. Also if you know how to strafe jump, this just slows you down.
Damage number display : Helps me out in knowing how much my rockets are doing, however it does allow you to track through walls better as long as the number is still up. Personally I would like to see this go.
New VO (Voice Over) : It was an unneeded change but after a while you can block it out.

Now for the worst of the worst...
Item timings : There's no need to count out your powerups anymore, you go near the PU spawn and it will tell you when it's up.
Last but not least, weapon loadout : No one, and I mean no one asked you to follow in activisions footsteps. I realize that you want to appeal to more gamers but quake was never meant to be easymode. To be waiting for an item spawn and only to have someone spawn right next to you and eat a rocket to the face or get railed isn't entirely what Q3/QL gameplay was supposed to be. You go build up your stack and then goto battle, you're not supposed to be babied. That's what CA is for, introducing this concept for FFA and TDM just means you're admitting defeat to CoD.
voteText: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Quake Live, one of the last arena shooters, which still gets played.

After the big update last month there was alot of hate. Understandable.
Let's first talk about that update.
There was alot of discussion about it.
The main topic is the new price, which is 10€. It was a bad move from Bethesda, just changing the price, thats for sure. But everybody who already had the game on Steam, keeps it in their library & can still play it. Also the Premium feature got removed, which makes nobody have advantages. The update also gave us a full Steam Support & making your own Server for you and your friends (which was a premium feature before). Also there was discussions about the removed Linux Support (Yeah, because so many people play on linux.). Im sorry about the people on Linux who can't play anymore.

So I personally think it's not that tragic and people are ♥♥♥♥♥ing too much and giving inappropriate ratings about the game, which itself is very good and funny, especially if youre playing together with your friends.

I don't support the idea of making a game 10€, but in this case we got something else from that.
And YES I recommend you buying this awesome game!

reviewText:
BYOUTIFUL. SIMPLY BYOUTIFUL.... Seriously though. I have always heard of Quake for years and years, and this game is seriously one of the best if not THE best online first person shooter game I've ever played.

Gameplay (10/10): The players are hostile and competitive and the action is fast paced and quite different at first until you get the hang of it all. But easily the gameplay is what makes Quake Live what it is.

Graphics (7/10): The reason why I say this is the fact that this game is an updated port of the 1999 Quake III Arena title. So while the graphics are very simplistic and not at all like the more known shooters of our time, the art and map design  are simply brillant so it makes up for it.

Controls (9/10): I love the controls. The game is very fast paced like I said, so the controls are kind of the same. Might not be for some people. But it comes over time.

Overall this game is just a great FPS especially for the fact it's free to play. Also they are not scamming the players with a free to play system like the others. It does have a premium features but all it includes is additional maps and the ability to make private lobbies, which really isn't a big deal.. Honestly, I'd pay money for this title if it wasn't free quite honestly. The game is simplistic, bare-boned, and filled with no holds barred action. It might simply not be for everyone but by god it is for me.

reviewText:
Product received for free

quake live is an arena shooter and basically the most complete and polished version of
quake 3 arena, which was released in december 1999 by id software.
the game has a pick up and play design, so everybody can join and have his portion of action packed combat: against bots, on lan with friends or online.

while the core mechanics of the game are easy to understand there is a huge depth to it
and it will take a long time to master. so when you go online to compete with others
be prepared to be destroyed by good players, since they may have been playing for over a decade.
considering playing online, quake live has the biggest player base when it comes to
arena shooters and if you are interested in the genre quake offers the best way to get started.

quake live is old school: it's hard, fast,
competitive with a lot of freedom and space for improvisation.
there are no such things like level up system, unlocks or health regenaration it's all about
the feeling you get when you improve: it's so satisfying!

every weapon is designed to fulfill a certain role and so it depends on situation, position, distance or healthstatus of the opponent which one works best.

when it comes to movment there is a lot to discover.
you can gain speed, height or position by using strafe jumping, circle jumps, rocket jumps
or even plasma climbs.

mapknowledge is key!
knowing where to find weapons, armor or health pick ups is extremly important.
the overall map design is great with classics like the campgrounds (q3dm6) or bloodrun (ztn).
the game offers a ton of them so i guess there should be something for everybody.

there are plenty of modes to play:

free for all
clan arena
duel
capture the flag
team deathmatch
instagib
freeztag
race
...

the game has aged extremely well, there are a lot of customisations you can make and it runs
smoothly at 125 fps on pretty much every computer.

since october 2015 quake live is available through steam only, and did get a nice bunch of updates considering things like a replay center for demo playback, valve anti cheat, voice chat, steamworks, dedicated servers, lan support, map packs with all the arenas they released over the years ...
id software keeps supporting the game in the form of releasing patches. i know there are people complaining about many things, but it's an incredibly good game, well balanced and definitively worth the money.

reviewText:
This is a valid reminder that games can be rebooted sucessfully and played really well.

THE PROS:
-Great gameplay
-A lot of character models
-Extremly Detailed Maps
-No Pay to play (but you can go Quake Live Pro to make your own servers and mess around with the maps)
-THEY SAVED ROCKET JUMPING!!!!
-Weapons do as they say in their description
-Fun as hell.

THE CONS:
-Every time the game detects a connection problem you cant move or cant see yourself moving.
-There are some players that have been playing previous Quake games for YEARS. (im one of them)
-NOT ENOUGH WEAPONS!

Overall though it is a really good game and you should play it.

reviewText:
I have nearly 2000 hours in that game. I have been beta tester also since 2009, since this game was long away from its Steam release - this game is simply the best FPS out there. You know why? - Because it's though, it's damn though (that's actually its positive but negative thing also) - learning curve is so damn long, because after 5 years of playing that game believe me - I don't know still to play that game properly. I am still newbie and I am glad that I am admiting that.
So if you're newcomer to this game, prepare for a lot of defeats, rages, etc, because there are a lot of players which have tons of xp from Quake3 Arena (remember, QuakeLive is basically 'the same' thing as Quake3) - but after couple of years you'll finally realize that you have learned something on this game.
Having pro in the game is absolute must if you're planning to play that game very often or if you want to have own servers ruled by your own rules.
So - I would recommend this game to everyone, because it's though game, if you like though games - then play it.
And please if you had any of Call of duty xp - PLEASE don't even try to compare QL to CoD series, it's completely different thing you know, because of hard and long learning curve in QuakeLive.
Greetings.

reviewText:
QuakeLive is a shooter without compromises ... on the rocks" ... no fancy extras[/h1]

Guess for everybody who has played Quake before no explenation is needed. - for everybody else:

Probably it will be not that easy for beginners within QuakeLive (QL). The game is based on the multiplayer-only classic QUAKE III ARENA (Dec'99). Because of that you'll meet an elite of gamers who are into that game over a decade! This can quickly crash your game experience but it could be also highly motivating. QL is surely one of the best examples for games that are "easy to learn but hard to master". For a reason eSport is a big topic if it comes to QUAKE at all.

But don't worry. Less experienced players are still "protected". Servers are splitted into "tiers" which indicate your level of experience / skill ... how this is calculated you can read on several pages
date:
within steam guides or in the QL-Forums[www.quakelive.com].

The game modes that QuakeLive offers meanwhile showing that it's more than just a Q3A/TA remake:
Free For All
Duel
Team Deathmatch
Clan Arena
Freezetag
Capture the Flag
1 Flag Capture the Flag
Attack & Defend
Harvester
Domination
Red Rover
Race
plus several variations (physics) for all modes like:  Insta
hoursPlayed:
Turbo

Why do i recommend this game?!It's free of charge and even without pay-option you'll have happy fragging times
endless maps from the original

reviewText:
Wow, there's a ♥♥♥♥ storm going on because Quake Live is switching from freemium + pro subscription to buy-to-play for $10.

First off, if you played QL previously before October and never switched to the Steam client, email support@quakelive.com and they will give you a key.  There, problem solved for 90% of the complaints.

Hackers have been a problem because they have been able to continuously make free aliases without penalty for hacking.  With the introduction of VAC and buy-to-play, this lessens the problem.  Free-to-play and competitive shooters do not mix, ever.  This is a good change.

Quake Live costs less than Q3A and has a greater population; those who are saying just buy Q3A lol" are full of ♥♥♥♥.  There's no logic behind that
recommended: $10 for a game that is going to stop being developed?  Reflex is also at that price point with occasional sales
hoursPlayed: is in alpha and is basically Quake now in the hands of competent people who know what they're doing.  Reflex is probably a better future-proof purchase for new people.\n\nQuake is great
voteText: but I have to unrecommend QL to new people until they lower the price to something more realistic.\n\nTL;DR too much unjustified whining from ex-players
helpfulPercent: but $10 is too much for new players due to Reflex also being $10 and still offering the Quake experience and actively developed."

reviewText: Played many Fps's all from Goldeneye and above. Wasted hours on Perfect Dark, Time splitters 2, Turok rage wars, 007 Agent under fire, Goldeneye, and many more. Found nine inch nails around the same time as Quake 1, and found Infected Mushroom through a Frag Movie from Quake 3 days, and 007 Agent Under Fire ran on the Quake 3 engine including star wars jedi knight jedi outcast. To this day still can prove and show how Quake is a more skilled based and chess like arena shooter and shooter in general. Guess you could say I'm a retro gamer at heart. Quake still continues to impress me from gameplay to community & skill. It's a game that can make every second of a bad day into a forgotten void. A game well deserved to be remembered.

reviewText: Quake Live is Quake3 just smoother and better looking. Now, on Steam it offers the user numerous mode options to choose from. There are servers running FFA, CTF, Freeze Tag, Duel, Clan Arena, and more. You can, also, find servers running variations with insta-gib, runes, grapple/hook, and Team Arena style power-ups. the configuration choices are endless. If you enjoy a fast paced shooter, then Quake Live will give you the twitch reflex fix you are looking for.\nI Love this game takes me back to the glory days of FPS games like the Unreal Tournament, and Quake franchises. Some say the FPS genre is fading, but I believe there is a renaissance starting here with Quake Live. Wrote this back in Nov 2015.

reviewText: Started QL in Jan. 2010 playing almost 5000 matches through the stand-alone launcher before switching over to steam for QL in August 2015.  If you enjoy arena fps, this is loads of fun!  QL is way more fun than other arena fps games that have almost no multi-players.   At least in QL, there is always a game to join (multi-player) - whether you like FFA, CTF, TDM, FreezeTag, Duel, CA, Racing, etc etc.   For new players, use the practice mode and learn how to move and use different weapons.  Find friends in the game itself and have fun.   Ya - there are hardcore veteran QL players, but there are also many casual players (me) who find the casual servers and have lots of fun!  You only get better the more you play.   I like to spectate the pro players (find their servers) and learn things that way too.  Well worth playing - for arena fps players.  Haha....people who find this review not helpful - get over your ego and have some fun.

reviewText:
The Steam release of Quake Live has been a long time coming, more than likely years too late, but with it Bethesda had a choice in how they were going to approach this opportunity to revitalise the game and get new players in.

They could either implement the crucial infrastructure needed by all classes of players (improved matchmaking, party system, tutorials, steamworks integration, even silly things like workshop), or determine that the problem lies in the game itself and try to make it more accessible".

Unfortunately
date: they went with the latter. Features such as "weapon loadouts"
recommended: universal ammo packs and pip timers decrease the crucial aspect of weapon/item control (Quake's defining dynamic). On-screen damage numbers were introduced. A new weapon was introduced to fill the "assault rifle" niche
hoursPlayed: the one niche that is neither needed nor wanted... and the LG
voteText: a crucial core weapon
helpfulPercent: was nerfed to allow for the new weapon to exist.\n\nImprovements to infrastructure could have added value to their subscription model and help vanquish the image problem that plagues Quake. Instead the misguided
votesHelpful: destructive and cynical approach is to dumb down the game and hide the "proper" game behind a paywall (a classic ruleset is available if you subscribe...).\n\nQuake is a strange game and always has been
votesTotal: and is very hard to make work in a large scale in the modern gaming environment - but this surely cannot be the way to do things.\n\n(I have not played the Steam version yet
votesFunny: but have played Quake in its various forms casually for over a decade and played the update that included most of these big changes.)"

reviewText:
Trust the Quake Live team to snatch defeat from the hands of victory at every. single. opportunity.

The move to full Steam integration and Workshop map delivery and all should have happened from the beginning. The game should have cost a nominal fee to play and be free, with no tiers or subscription nonsense, from the beginning. You should have been able to play all maps, against bots, locally, since the beginning (or at least consistently, because they've waffled back and forth on that over the years). There should never have been a wonky, half-♥♥♥♥♥, web-based launcher at all.

This game, as it stands now, with the move to full Steam integration, in November 2015, is the game QL should always have been -- a worthy extension of Quake 3, the best damned deathmatch game ever.

But, no. They're charging too much, and although I don't give a damn about stats because the complete mishandling of this game I should have loved without reserve put me off from getting too involved years back, there's no freaking way they should have trashed the stats of people who've been playing it regularly for the last 5 years. The fact that they thought that would be OK just shows the utter contempt for (or total lack of understanding of) their player base that has seemingly informed nearly every decision along the road.

It's a bummer, because it's too late. Hardcore players who've been into Q3 for 16 years, or even hardcore QL players who've come to it in the last 5, are going to continue playing. But nobody's going to pay 10BUX for this game if they weren't already a fan.

Which makes no sense at all, yet again. They spend time fiddling with stuff to make it more accessible for 'modern players', but just alienating old-schoolers. Then they wipe everybody's stats and start charging ten bucks for a once-free game (with ludicrously dumb subscription tiers, now thankfully gone, at least) which will drive off casuals, but once again alienating old-schoolers who they've now made their primary potential purchasers.

It has been, at every step over the years, as if they actually didn't want anybody to play this. If that was the goal, they've done one heck of a job trying to achieve it.

All that said, though: I love this game. I recommend it. I think this version, as of November 2015, like I said, is what it should have been all along. I'm probably just going to use it to fire up localhost Nightmare bot matches, like I've done for a decade and half with Q3, just to relax, but that's all I ever really wanted. A modernish, better-looking, easier-to-launch version of Quake 3, with an easy way to find and add new maps when I feel the urge.

And that's what we've got. I'd probably even pay TENBUX for it if I didn't own it already, but just barely, and it's been my favorite deathmatch game since Q3Test in 1999. Which means your average CALL OF DOODY player almost certainly... won't.

reviewText:
Great simple shoot-till-their-dead-simulator; This for 2 bucks makes me wonder why some people don't own it yet.

It's a game that makes you hate it but as you play more and more you learn how to get better.
It's a game about raw skill, and there is definitely a fine curve in playtime to skill.
First you learn what each weapon does, and then you figure out how everyone is using them to learn how to use them yourself.
You pick up tricks from watching other people play, such as rocket jump spots.
It's a game about knowing your opponent, and not letting them know you. To win is not just to outshoot, but to outthink and to outtime and outmaneuver your opponent takes years of practice.
Don't think you care enough to practice hard for 10 years? You don't really have to, but if you play to be the best that's what it takes.
Movement is a big part of the game as well. Simple things like walking can get really deep: wallstrafing, circlejumping, rocket and plasma jumps are all very commonly heard phrases and very useful tricks.
Its a game about anything for an advantage." Previously mentioned movement techniques finely tuned on specific portions of maps can provide just the slightest fraction of a second cut off to get to the red armor before your opponent (which provides 100 armor points and is a very good advantage)
Its a game about knowing what fights to take. You may have all the rockets
hoursPlayed: but you wont make it far with just 25 hp and 30 armor. (this is where knowing not only where weapons spawn
voteText: but health spawns and what kind of health can provide a great edge in the game)\nIt's a great casual game as well

reviewText:
I was connected to North American servers several times, and, being an Australian, had lag issues on a scale the world has never seen. Rockets actually appearing to fire thirty seconds behind actually firing, lightning guns that didn't hit, the players I was shooting being thirty seconds in the future. Latency problems aside, the game is Quake 3. Now, don't get me wrong, Quake 3 is awesome, but Live adds new features that have brought the rage and hatred of veterans.

A change I didn't like was picking your starter weapon.
Now, I cannot comprehend why they would do such a thing, as part of the fun in Quake 3 was scrambling to find a weapon more powerful than your starting maching gun, and for me, it was trying to find the rocket launcher before anyone else, but here, it just gives you a rocket launcher. Now, I both love and hate this, partially because new players can spawn with an instagib weapon immediately, and partially that I can spawn in with a rocket launcher, ready to confuse and juggle anyone with the poor judgement to enter my line of sight.

So, one thing to make Quake Live better is to have better matchmaking, taking location into account, so Australians and other people who live in countries far, far away from where the main servers are, can get into a decent game that doesn't cause a temporal anomaly, and maybe reduce the starter weapon pool to weaker versions of the guns.
(i.e a mini-rocket launcher that has rockets do less damage, and have a smaller blast radius.)

Until then, however, this game is a no-go from me.

reviewText:
I'll be honest, I'm not actually sure what the transition to Steam achieved for id Software and the others who contribute to the development of the game, but it's happened. We move on.

The game is a first-person shooter. EXTREMELY fast paced. If you're coming from a game such as Call of Duty, you WILL need time AND patience to get on your feet in this game. With that said, once you've found your ground, the satisfaction of shooting a rocket at an enemy while airbourne to bring them down, or finishing them off with a rail. None other compares.
Many game types, so it ranges from a solo player to a team player, everyone is satisfied.
The game mechanics are a little weird in that movement is more inclusive from the player's side meaning that the player will have to become skilled at movement as they progress through the tiers. Remember, you're a hot knife going through butter, be that knife in battle and you'll do great things.

Highly, highly recommend this game to others. If not for the sake of the history of Quake, then for the sake of the game Quake. You will NEVER play a game like this, I guarantee it.

There is a huge, diverse group of players from all over the world playing here, and many of them are skilled.

Patience, determination, and enjoyment. Seriously, this is actually a great, fun game. You'll be fine, newbie. ♠

reviewText:
Lots of ♥♥♥♥ going on with QL after the 2 most recent updates. They sprung a price of $10 on the game and it's made a lot of people unhappy.

I enjoy playing Quake Live. It's the most fun I've ever had playing a game, and the most I've ever played one specific game. It's easy to keep coming back to time and time again, because at the end of the day it's a pure Arena Shooter - every game starts on equal terms, and it's down to player skill how it goes. Loadout servers are the exception, but those servers are boring ;)

Some people are arguing that now the game costs money they'll just play Quake 3 instead, but Q3 is still rediculously overpriced on Steam. Buy this instead, and you'll actually be abl to play with people. If you're sitting on the fence, wait for it to go on sale.

This game's had it's problems, but it's a classic everyone should try it. Very strongly reccomend!

reviewText: Quake in general has been one of my favorite games, it has just the right combination of speed, making it not too fast for the new players, and just the right speed for the veterans. Quake is one of the better end fast paced shooters out there, making for great gameplay for all players. My one problem is I use to play Quake live quite a lot in the past. When I came back to try it on steam, the client itself seemed to be extremely slow or laggy, even when I got in game on the lowest graphics possible it still seemed to be extremely choppy and laggy. I meet WAY past the minimum requirements to run this game yet I can't seem to run it. I'm not sure if it's a problem with the client but I've done my research and many other players seem to have this problem. While this doesn't matter to some of you crazed fast paced gunman already in game, it kinda blows it just to want to play the game and have it run like this. I can definitly recommend this game to anyone that likes fast paced competitive shooters, but just hope you don't get the same problem a lot of us are having. So in conclusion, good game, I recommend, just some problems.

reviewText:
For me, it is THE perfectly designed game. The recent relaunch on Steam has brought a lot of modern-day polish. Start any kind of server and watch people join. The community is even pumping out mods already just like back then in the old days. Is it worth 10$ today? Absolutely.

If you're a newcomer and are frightened by the skill ceiling: like any well-designed sport / game, it gets fun when you know how to play it. Feel free to ask me for help, or other people in the forum / on reddit. There are stupid people and helpful people like everywhere. Find the helpful ones.

If you're a returning veteran: no more bots kicking you off the servers.

If you're wondering whether there are still people playing this old game: here in Europe, it's not CS GO but definitely enough.

Some background info: I currently own 303 games, and this is the first Steam review I write. Because Quake Live as it is today is worth my time and your time. I played it back then as Quake 3 Arena and joined the arena again when it was free. And am very happy with the product as it is today.

(Sorry if there are English mistakes; non-native speaker.)

reviewText:
Excellent Quake game with the best weapon balance in my opinion. Its free, its competitive and its fast paced.

Its also worth noting that the new changes (like loadouts) arent mandatory and many players arent playing gametypes or on servers that have loadouts enabled. If you dont like them and think they are too casual, dont play on those servers and stick to classic quake. Duel hasnt changed at all and CTF doesnt have loadouts in classic or default. For everything else there are clasic servers.

Quake is still Quake. Only you can now decide if you want to play the newcomers ruleset or the classic.

reviewText:
One of the tell-tale signs your son is a computer hacker is if he uses Quake.

6. Does your son use Quake?

Quake is an online virtual reality used by hackers. It is a popular meeting place and training ground, where they discuss hacking and train in the use of various firearms. Many hackers develop anti-social tendencies due to the use of this virtual world, and it may cause erratic behaviour at home and at school.

If your son is using Quake, you should make hime understand that this is not acceptable to you. You should ensure all the firearms in your house are carefully locked away, and have trigger locks installed. You should also bring your concerns to the attention of his school.
However, this review is not about Quake. It is about Quack Live, where players run around like they're on quake crack. It's much better than that CS Go Away" rubbish that everyone raves about. But not as good as UT. They made some stupid decisions like the loadouts and universal ammo features. Unlike UT though

reviewText:
I can't think of a single game on Steam I could recommend more to anyone than Quake Live. If you are unfamiliar with the Quake series then this game is a super fast-paced multiplayer FPS which combines skill and strategy to pit players against one another in a variety of different game modes and maps. Despite the pure brilliance of this game many sorry people still choose to write negative reviews on this game. Most of these people are either hard-core fans of the classic Quake games and would complain of any changes made to their much beloved Quake 3 Team Arena. The other people are just plain idiots.

Yes, just a few months ago at time of writing this game was 100% free-to-play on Steam. And now the game costs $9.99 ($1.99 Steam Sales), which I am honestly surprised Bethesda didn't charge for this brilliant game from the very beginning. These idiots who played the game before the paid update were constantly told to change to Steam for this game before it became paid to recieve a free copy like me. But for many that was obviously much to hard and depressing when the paid update came.

So new players are probably wondering why should I buy this brilliant game, perhaps cause you permanently recieve all the benfeits that some fools used to pay $40 a month to subscribe to before the update!!!

The update itself improves the game massively with a new much easier to navigate interface, lobby hosting and so much more which players had been requesting for years! The game itself is something you must commit to a few hours a week to become competent/competitive somewhat like csgo. Except csgo is not a thoroughly modern revamp of one of the best FPS games of all time! Bethesda has finally made good on all their promises for this game and Quake Live is more worth it now especially at Sale time than ever before. 10/10

reviewText:
TL;DR There wont ever be a Arena FPS on the same level as Quake, RIP Unreal Tournament & Arena Shooters in general.

Put simply, the Ultimate Game of Skill.

There's no easy way around it, no arguements to settle... simply no reason to disprove the statement above; because no other game offers the same mechanics like Quake does, arena shooter or otherwise. We can't even compare its age old rival Unreal Tournament, since that game has been chopped and changed throughout the years... its really just a cheap knockoff. (Not taking out UT99's Facing Worlds... excellent map) Quake's formula remains unchanged since its original incarnation and has stood the test of time.

And plus to compare any shooter to Quake is like comparing Apples to Oranges.

Quake is set apart from other FPS or Arena shooters by having a near perfect engine for precise control and movement, very efficient netcode carried over from the excellent netcode of Quake 3 means that the game feels like a LAN-Party even with 50-100 ping... however I don't recommend playing games over 100.

The gameplay also differs from the fact there's no random variables, no luck based elements involved. The entire game is set about by chance"... the chance that a rocket might hit... but that is all controlled by you the player
date: since every weapon has 100% accuracy and movement is considerably faster than any other FPS. There are no "headshots" or easy kills
recommended: it simply doesn't exist and therefore does not hold your hand in the chance you 'may' get a random headshot as such. If someone kills you repeatedly its just a sign they're a far better player than you are.\n\nThis system allows people to play with consistency that isn't often seen in other games
hoursPlayed: you never really lose the skills you had in Quake... more likely people just get better than you are
voteText: the engine is timeless. There's also Map Control to consider
helpfulPercent: don't want to pick up items? Expect to respawn very quickly. You simply can't play the traditional gametypes successfully without trying to get the items on the map
votesHelpful: you don't start with power weapons (loadouts are now an option thank god) and thus you're at a tremendous disadvantage the moment you spawn.\n\nSo with no easy entrance for beginners why do I recommend this game? Quake is the only game that offers a true 100% skill based Competitive Experience
votesTotal: the fact there's no random variables should be plainly obvious. Games like CSGO do have an excellent competitive community (though salty D:)
votesFunny: but there is always going to be a random element in the game. The Quake Community is truly amazing
commentsCount: do poorly in a game vs a better player... they'll critique you
column16:
give you tips etc... you get the odd elitist but the reception overall is awesome. :3

Also the new update is great imho... sure its Pay 2 Play... but so was Quake Live Premium and that was BS. If you had Quake Live on Steam beforehand you got it free... so why all the commotion?

Stands the Test of Time. 10/10

"

reviewText:
Excellent Quake game with the best weapon balance in my opinion. Its free, its competitive and its fast paced.

Its also worth noting that the new changes (like loadouts) arent mandatory and many players arent playing gametypes or on servers that have loadouts enabled. If you dont like them and think they are too casual, dont play on those servers and stick to classic quake. Duel hasnt changed at all and CTF doesnt have loadouts in classic or default. For everything else there are clasic servers.

Quake is still Quake. Only you can now decide if you want to play the newcomers ruleset or the classic.

reviewText:
Quake Live is my favorite game. Why? It's fast-paced, takes skill, makes you laugh, and is pretty cussin' fun.

Quake is often described as a game that's easy to learn but impossible to master. You can get set up quickly and a sense of why the movement, gameplay, sounds, and visuals (as old as they are) are intoxicating. And, yet, some people have been playing for years, are scary good, and it takes some time to learn the game to compete with them.

It's had many iterations and, like chess, is really well balanced. As I read in a post once, in Quake you don't wait to get better weapons or items to improve, when you get better, you realize it was your own hard work that got you there. And it’s totally gratifying when you can start to hang with folks who schooled you before.

I can see how some people are critical of some of the changes (and I myself miss the Quake 2 Capture the Flag days). But to be honest, the addition of new maps with the Steam conversion has breathed new life into the game.

A tip for the newcomers: learn to weather the curmudgeons. One of my favorite things about playing Quake Live is the community. If you play often you get to know people and joking around with them is half the fun. However, there are some sour grapes in the mix who will treat you poorly and might kick you off a server. So, a) you might need to learn to have a thick skin and b) consider starting with the Free For All games at first before joining some of the team games.

Bottom line: Quake rules. Join the party.

reviewText:
On first impressions as a first time 'Quaker' this seems to be a very fast paced game to which a lack of lag does wonders for.

Sure it's dated in the graphics (hardly the end of the world), but aside from a little bit of keybinding i need to do later so i can access it easier it has fun and fast paced gameplay that with understanding from playing the tutorial (very important to explaining things) and a little bit of practice from other games that have carried quake's ideas and implemented them into thier own *cough*TF2*cough* it can slowly creep up on you with addictiveness.

I intend to play it more in the future and would recommend to others (however if you're not as satisfied as me, the seperate login account can be deactivated by visiting the site)

reviewText:
On first impressions as a first time 'Quaker' this seems to be a very fast paced game to which a lack of lag does wonders for.

Sure it's dated in the graphics (hardly the end of the world), but aside from a little bit of keybinding i need to do later so i can access it easier it has fun and fast paced gameplay that with understanding from playing the tutorial (very important to explaining things) and a little bit of practice from other games that have carried quake's ideas and implemented them into thier own *cough*TF2*cough* it can slowly creep up on you with addictiveness.

I intend to play it more in the future and would recommend to others (however if you're not as satisfied as me, the seperate login account can be deactivated by visiting the site)

reviewText:
Came to Steam to overcome CS:GO.

Because QL is the most competitive FPS yet.
No game can deny your skill in the genre better: you think you're good in FPSs? Meh. In QL you'll see what a noob you really are... And that's not an insult to anyone –– to master Quake Live is what it takes to be a real pro FPS gamer. No other game will test your aim, reaction & thinking speed better.

Pure FPS experience as it should be: F2P, no P2W & no sh**. Unbeatable since and for ages.
10/10

reviewText:
10 dollar version of Quake III: Arena.

This is still the Quake III (althoug slightly watered down) that we know. Skill is prevelant here, with hackers almost no where to be found.

Various game modes offer fun time for whatever style you wanna play, with some more modes offered if you buy a subscription. You can customize your play expereince pretty throughly, and it's just a great fun game all around. The Community is also really friendly.

90's gameplay stylings are highly prevelant here, however, such as advanced rocket jumping, Bunny Hopping, and grenade jumping to name a few, so if you dive head first into the quick play option, don't be surprised if you see other players bounding around the map at mach 4. That's what makes Quake fun anyway.

10 bucks, under a gig, highly customizible, and fun. Grab it and frag you noids.

reviewText:
Game is dead, the only people left playing are the botters.
Even people who were known for being avg and getting vote kicked out of Tier 4 just a year ago, are now hitting over 50% LG. People follow you through walls, you sneak around with gaunt and they rail your face as soon as you poke your head out.
Then there's the morons defending them, saying how they are just really good at this game.......which apparently makes you psychic.
I've been playing QL since beta, and I've watched as 30% LG acc used to mean you were amazing and it just kept climbing.
Now if you join any CA match, the avg LG at then end if over 40% for everyone.

Big problem now though, there's nobody to report cheaters to. At least before you could spectate, record demo and report suspected cheaters to iD support and an actual person would review the demo.
Now? You can click on report" on someone's username. But there's no longer support for this game since it's gone to Steam. It's come here to die
recommended:
and smells like almonds.
Someone should come around and put it out of it's misery with a double barrelled shotgun to the head.

RIP Quakelive."

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SlCRfTmBSGs
It's a free version of what is arguably the greatest multiplayer deathmatch game ever made. No P2W, No DLC, No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Go get it if you enjoy playing oldschool deathmatch style games and are willing to accept serious challenge and difficulty that will take practice to master. Some purists may bicker that this version of Quake III has some new changes/implementations, but honestly, i dont mind them. The game has been around for a long time and it definitely needed some new features to keep it fresh.

Highly Recommended. 9/10

reviewText:
For just 10 bucks surely a great game to own, but read on...

Since the change from subscriptions to Steam Bethesda has again shown that they have very little or no regard for the community playing the game. Not showing any interest in its player base, clans. Neglecting the fact this community has put lots of effort and time into better organizing matches using external tools to balance skills on servers running team based modes such as TDM, CA and CTF. Neglecting the fact many of these players have been playing and supporting Quake since the nineties, organizing tournaments, writing mods to enhance and improve teamplay, etc. etc.

With this change to the Steam platform people have lost their playerstats, their clans, their lists of friends and most of all the desire to play the game any longer. The result is games where the good players disconnect out of frustration over the many unskilled players destroying any form of teamplay.

Quake WAS a game for high skilled players and was at the cradle of e-sports when it first appeared. Now it has turned into a nubflooded waste of time.

Well played Bethesda, you have finally managed to kill Quake.

We need the Barrysworld and Q3A times back. Where are you Biffy?

reviewText: Quake is a legendary series and made by the software company that introduced us to First Person Shooters, ID Software. I was a fan of Quake, Quake 2 and Quake 3. What I love about QuakeLIVE is they took a very difficult game to get involved in, because of; patches, mods, maps, servers, configurations, and the other details you might need to look into before you started playing. Now QuakeLIVE takes Quake 3, touches it up, makes it super simple to get playing, patches automatically and now even gives you the ability to have a membership that allows you to host private games. Since this game is free, there's no reason you shouldn't at least try it out.

reviewText:
Every helpful review right now is veterans bawling over the changes.
Not saying the changes aren't bad, I mean, loadouts?

BUT loadouts don't hurt the game anywhere near as bad as people think. Most of it is exaggeration on the part of veteran players who were shocked to hear about some casual-♥♥♥ shit like that.

But it doesn't hurt. Just give the game a try. It's free so there's no reason not to. Sure, elements have been casualized but in the end, it's still runny jumpy dashy shooty Quake 3 Arena.

Also, there is a PLANNED UPDATE that will get rid of loadouts, add blood and the removed maps back to the game, as well as giving the community servertools, which at this point will make it basically a complete, free Q3A.

reviewText:
My all time favourite is now on Steam! :D I used to play Quake Live now and then, but everyone was playing Clan Arena (team last man standing, like Counter Strike). I could not really enjoy that mode, so eventually I quit.  Now it's back with a few modifications.

The biggest change is a positive one imo: you get to start out with 2 weapons of your choice with a little bit of ammo. This solves the problem of getting spawnkilled all the time because you only have the machine gun (and the gauntlet) and the enemy has a fully loaded rocket launcher, lightning gun and heavy armor. At least now you are able to defend yourself with your weapon of choice and it allows you to jump straight into the action.

Finding a game is even easier than it was before: just pick form a category you want to play and it will find a game for you (a la Team Fortress). It seems all the game modes are now accessible for everyone (including Freeze Tag, yay!). There are some new game modes from Q3: Team Arena, such as Red Rover and Harvester.

I guess the community will get quite an influx of newbs, but that is fine (more fragfood, heh), at least people are still playing Q3. This is just the uncomplicated multiplayer fun I was looking for. No unlockable weapons/perks, no hats, no (god forbid) pay-to-win; just the old-skool fragging.

reviewText:
Quake at Steam!


In 1996, the audience at a big local LAN-party was like 50% Counter-Strike and 50% Quake; both scenes in one hall with a huge split between them. Quake was the better game, because of the netcode and the physics, but Counter-Strike was more thrilling to me for it's realism. Bought Half-Life to play Counter-Strike and I still remember the day Valve forced Steam on me to play CS... and here we are: the mighty Valve-steampower with a tribute to a legend: QUAKE!

THIS IS FPS!

It's hard, fast, exact and reliable! This is not just a game, it's a great hand-eye-coordination-workout, a high-speed parcours, the epic rocket arena or just the ultimate challenge of your mechanical skills.

Play this game!

reviewText:
Quake III and, by extension, Quake Live, is perhaps the best multiplayer FPS ever made.

Don't let the newcomer friendly changes scare you off if you're experienced, and if you've never played multiplayer Quake? Come on in, it's free!

The weapons may seem a little restrained compared to its contemporaries like Unreal Tournament, but the balance is unmatched. Each weapon has situations where it shines, and situations where it's awful.

There's lots of modes available, it should run on most any computer, and it's free (no pay2win at all), so you've nothing to lose.

reviewText:
What the hell? A five+ year old game that was free now costs money? Thanks, Bethesda.

OLD REVIEW:
I recommend this to everyone, but especially people who have never tried Quake or people that are looking for a good old game.

Great quake game, fast paced first person shooter. Very fair, everyone has the same capabilities and leveling up is not here.

My one problem: the menus are the worst menus out of literally any game I've played in my life. The menu is not built in: it is loaded from the internet EVERY time you click on something. So, if you want to play a game, it needs to reload the game selection screen, etc. and if it decides not to work you're out of luck. I couldn't change matches today because it didn't work. I couldn't even get back to the selection screen for different modes.

reviewText:
THE old school FPS experience. If you never played this, prepare to get wrecked on your first tries :P

Pros:
-No leveling up, no unlockables, no pay2win, which means that the only factor needed to win is skill.

Cons:

-You can either be in a match and wreck or be wrecked  if you have the bad luck of going against a pro. (matchmaking, anyone?)

reviewText:
Quake III and, by extension, Quake Live, is perhaps the best multiplayer FPS ever made.

Don't let the newcomer friendly changes scare you off if you're experienced, and if you've never played multiplayer Quake? Come on in, it's free!

The weapons may seem a little restrained compared to its contemporaries like Unreal Tournament, but the balance is unmatched. Each weapon has situations where it shines, and situations where it's awful.

There's lots of modes available, it should run on most any computer, and it's free (no pay2win at all), so you've nothing to lose.

reviewText: Quake Live reminds me that gameplay still matters. There's no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that gets in the way - you can have your 130FOV, completely customizable configs, your choice in mouse inputs, the whole nine yards - it's just you and your raw FPS skills.\n\nThe Steam update streamlined the game in some areas, but only in the modes that the professional scene doesn't touch much upon anyways; Duel and CTF remained the way they were. For the rest of us, Quake Live is the perfect way to experience some  timeless arena FPS gameplay.

reviewText:
I've been going for 5 years strong on Quake Live.  We've always joked that the community never received new people, as the players with names that no one has ever seen were just players smurfing.

For the most part, we were right.

The game has had it's massive ups and downs.  It features a super tight community of players that basically end up as close friends giving each other ♥♥♥♥.. Even when they're thousand of miles away.

The game has been receiving a lot of updates recently that has changed some elements of the game, but still leaves the core of the game in full effect for veterans to continue to do what they love the most.

There is a massive learning curve with the game, but like anything, you'll learn how to concur your problems by repetition and learning from your mistakes.  Overall the game is very fun. It's very fast paced, and almost any computer that has an internet connection can run this game.

reviewText:
Quake Live Review
fast Paced, Carnage (If you play right)

Context
Quake is a series that I have experienced but in the past never really played, I played Quake 2 on the PS1 (with keyboard and mouse) and have played around 40 hours of Quake 3 Arena. I will Reviewing this game after 10 hours  on 2/2/16.

What to know!
Quake Live is an online arena FPS, It is very fast paced especially compared to most modern FPS games and requires quite a bit of skill and alot of skill against experienced players, however Quake Compared to other games like it allows new players to easily learn the basics.

Quake Live is very accessable but players will most definely need a mouse as a trackpad or controller is hard to control at high speeds. If you stop or hit a wall most of the time you might as well be dead, it is a veryyfun game to play against friends as it is easily runnable.

Many people may ask:  Why should I buy this game over Quake 3
date: as it only seems to remove gibs"?\nI would reccomend this over Quake 3 for the following reasons
hoursPlayed:
the lack of gibs keeps a low age rating in most countries.
Games are easier to find and it is easier to play with friends
It recives more updates keeping the game as optimized as possible.
Final thoughts!
I think Quakelive is a great game even for those new to the series
voteText:
It is fun very faced paced and even though it requires alot of skill it is easy enough to learn if you want to put the time in.

I would say this game if well worth it's price tag and prefer the paid system to the old subscriber one

I rate Quake Live ♫♫♫♫♪ out of ♫♫♫♫♫ (4.5/5)"

reviewText:
Product received for free

It's Quake 3, but with a larger playerbase, better UI, better support for modern systems without a source port and optional noob-friendly features within servers. It's also cheaper.

If you're on Linux, get Quake 3 and play it with ioQuake3.

If you've been playing Quake Live for years and don't like the fact that you're being charged for it now, you should have switched to the Steam version earlier.

If you say that a Quake game shouldn't cost money now since it's so old, stop saying that old-school classics are better than all other games on the market.

If you're someone who doesn't like having to pay ten dollars for a game, you're probably not a part of the developers' target market.

Oh, yeah; Quake Live used to be free-to-play. Hopefully you don't complain about any other free-to-play games around, because that would be hyprocritical.

Basically, STOP COMPLAINING. There's always OpenArena, anyway.

reviewText:
The Quake series is classic. It's probably the most influential shooter when it comes to online arena/deathmatch  gameplay. If you haven't spent time playing it yet, you've missed out, and now is your chance to make up for that by testing out the waters with Quake Live.

So what exactly is Quake Live? Quake Live is basically a free game of the year edition remake for Quake III Arena. Same graphics engine, very similar gameplay, except it has significant patches to the netcode and functionality. But best of all, it's on now on Steam. Unlike modern shooters, Quake won't reward you for getting kills with airstrikes and UAVs or ammo drops. The only thing rewarding in Quake is your skill.

Quake III Arena in particular had a lot of gothic art and influence, which hasn't been dropped out of Quake Live, although it seems a bit minimalized. Quake is probably the reason I turned out emo/goth/scene/indie. When I was a kid it exposed me to blood, gore, and gothic art. It's weird to say but Quake was my first FPS ever, and actually had a profound influence on how I turned out.

If you loved Quake or even if you still haven't played it, download Quake Live now and start fragging away.
