reviewText:
I'm not too familiar with this genre, only played Unreal 2004 before and lord gaben do I love that game. Sadly we don't have constant Asian servers so I dropped it. Quake live is all I can ask for a fast-paced FPS. It has pretty much everything done right and is full of love. Only bad thing is no mod and (most importantly) private dedicated server support, which I suppose is because of the business model. It sucks but I don't necessarily hate that as it enables the F2P model. I'd choose to better expand the community than my personal needs everyday of the week, assuming ID do their jobs responsibly.

There's a lot of hate around the new face. I don't understand the mindset of those 'hardcore' players whining about loadouts and timers because the changes made it too easy and ruined the game. Yeah, how DARE they made the mechanic more accessible to new players so this dying genre could get a new chance. Not to mention organise all those tournaments, develop new engine and polished interface, set the basic game F2P(which is not restraining at all to ♥♥♥♥ING CASUALS) so the community may actually grow which of course means nothing to the hardcore esport. We need to pay for a full featured product? How dare ID suck money on the game they created in the first place. What a RIPOFF.

To clarify, they didn't change it entirely. Think of a Casual Mode (as in counter strike).

After an update, Pro subscription is only useful to spawn a server (not hosted locally but 'rented' on the master servers). No gameplay features are limited afaik. I bought a 2-month and found it useless..

reviewText:
One of the most perfect Arena Shooters ever made. Still retains that speed you remember and it has a ton of listed gamemodes that I'm sure someone will find their home in. Freeze Tag, Team Deathmatch, Free For All, Duel, Domination, etc. And the connection feels pretty good, or at least I haven't noticed any strong connectivity issues or lag with the servers I've played on.

Quake Live updates the original Quake III with some changes like adding loadouts, which consist of a 'primary' and 'secondary' starting weapon. You can still pick up the many various weapons throughout the maps or off dead players, like usual, it just gives people some more opportunities to get started without waiting for a Rocket Launcher or your favorite weapon to start blasting some fools. At first it seems really scary, but I think this change quickens the pace and I definitely see it as for the better.

I can't comment too much on the new maps, if there are any? I assume there are. Because there are certainly maps I'm unfamiliar with. I dig most of 'em. A few kinda have a weird flow to it that I'm not really sure I find as fun as the others, but they're still pretty solid maps. I have not seen all of 'em.

Other changes:
-There's a new weapon, the Heavy Machine Gun. It's definitely stronger than that starting one. *shrug* I dunno seems alright, I don't use it at all.

-Damage numbers. I don't think these were in the original. It's been so long. But it's definitely useful seeing how much damage the AoE of that rocket did.

-The powerups have a visible cooldown so that everyone can more easily understand when Quad Damage is available or whatever. This definitely makes it easier for new players to understand when and where they are supposed to be. I totally dig this change, because I'd NEVER be familiar with the timing otherwise.

A couple complaints...
-You can't vote to change a map unless you pay for the ability to both vote and make your own server. I suppose I don't really see what else you could pay for so that they could get some cash off of this free-to-play version of Quake III Arena, but I'm not the biggest fan of the voting aspect.

-The other big issue is that, at least when I play (mid-day or at night) there are a whole lot of empty servers. The community is seemingly tight and I wish there were more servers with people playing in them because this has been the only first person shooter I've ever not got frustrated with. Community seems to be pretty alright, the ones that are there.

In the end, I recommend giving this a go if you love arena shooters or loved Quake III at the time and wanna relive the days where everything you did felt so good. I also want you to give it a go because I need to see some new blood in here. Or old blood. Quake is old. You are old. Play this old game. It's everything I want in a shooter and I was a child-baby when this game came out originally.

reviewText:
Just like Quake 3.

I never really liked the browser version because there weren't custom servers (and I had around 100+ ping everywhere), and it just wasn't customizable at all.

I picked this up yesterday, and played a few matches of Clan Arena and FFA, and its pretty much Q3 with a little bit of a graphics boost - very hard to notice though.

It's great that the game is alive and well. Unfortunately, gone are the nice fun people I remember staying up all night with. Now we have kids running the tiny scene who seem to be carbon copies of the kids running the CS scene.

With such a small community, you'd think people would want to welcome newbies/oldbies, but it seems the hubris of today's children doesn't have time for such little formalities. A shame.

I recommend the game because Quake 3 is alive!!! But I probably won't play it for long if I have to have my relaxation ruined by a toxic community.

reviewText:
Despite the lower playtime shown on Steam, I am an older player of Quake Live before the game went on Steam. I decided to just now convert my QL account to Steam since the external launcher will be discontinued, even though the Steam version of QL launched quite a while ago. I started my account on December 21, 2009 with a total of 3:04:18:51 Ranked time and 13:19 Unranked time. In addition I have amassed several Awards over the course of my QL playtime.

Quake Live is basically the free to play version of Quake 3 Arena. That's all there really is to it. This is not a bad thing at all, because Q3A and by extension QL both have the one unique and strong point of the game: the gameplay. A true fast paced arena shooter, Quake Live lends itself to quality competitive gameplay relying not just on reflexes but also timing and positioning. Knowing how and when to use multiple weapons for the right situation along with mastery of movement options such as strafe jumping are key to high level play. Item timing is also crucial, leading to the necessary map knowledge across Quake's varied map designs. Most of the competitive play is set in Duel, but more casual modes such as Deathmatch and Capture the Flag also exist. A personal favorite is Clan Arena, granting all players all the weapons and full health and armor, perfect for practicing techniques in a team based gamemode. Whatever gamemode you pick, the gameplay is refined yet complex with many options available at your disposal.

Since Quake Live is pretty much a reskinned Quake 3 Arena, it looks and sounds much like its predecessor too. The graphics have not been updated too much, looking like an early 2000s game. I find that the graphics aged well and that it's not terribly ugly, while still maintaining clean visual clarity for competitive situations. The sounds are still good quality, and it is important to know what is happening in the middle of a fight with unique sounds for everything. While music is not a very important thing in a competitive title, Quake 3 Arena's soundtrack is quite nice. It's a bit dated electronic music, but still holds up for a good listen outside of the game.

Quake Live is one of the best competitive FPS games around. It is essentially a repackaging of Quake 3 Arena, but it has all the solid competitive gameplay that still plays great along with a strong community around it. The game overall has been more streamlined for a modern, smooth, and great experience. While the changes from the developers might scare some, they shouldn't since at its core, Quake Live has the unique gameplay that holds up strongly for a rewarding and competitive game.

reviewText:
Considering you're paying half the price of Quake 3 Arena to essentially play what is an updated, highly customisable version of it, sure I can reccommend it. As long as you have people willing to play with you.

It does not include Quake 3's singleplayer ladder mode (bot matches still exist in Live though), and I can't comment on online play at this current time but the game for the last five years has been tiny and overwhelmingly skilled. Again, I would reccommend playing with friends especially if you're new to arena shooters.

If you already own Quake 3 however, you're basically spending $10 on a massive patch. You will have to weigh the positives and negatives yourself.

reviewText: I recommend this game. But I almost becoming more and more aware of it's issues.\nThe fact that skill based match making" is more of a lie then a truth
date: is pretty disturbing. Why throw someone who's only played for 2 days in with people who get 40 kills on average per game? That's absolutely no fun for someone just trying to understand and comprehend the physics and actions of the game on a level where you can actually compete against other decent players. I want to play this game a lot
recommended: I want to spend a lot of time in it
hoursPlayed: but it's really just no fun having to play against the same 20-30 people that are on the servers in my area every single day. I feel like my review would be much more positive if there were simply more people playing this game on a daily basis. Someone who's played this game for 5+ years has a major advantage over someone who's only just starting
voteText: and it really ruins what appears to be a really great game. I can't say that many other games have had genuine "skill based match making" but this game seems to completely throw that option out of the window. Where are the servers full of new players? Where are the servers for veterans to duke it out? I feel like if this trend of dealing with large portions of highly skilled players with no alternatives but to play against them are my only options

This game doesn't suddenly suck because it costs 10usd.
It's still a fantastic deal: The definitive version of Quake 3 Arena with the best mods and maps and optimized for modern systems for just 10 dollars and no membership fee. There's even Workshop support.

reviewText: I have to admit - when I first came across Quake Live, it was kind of a turnoff. Sure, the browser thing was neat, but all the subscription paywalls meant I couldn't enjoy the real game without cranking out 34 bucks a year. Later, it came to Steam. I got it, still didn't play it often. When that easy-access update with the loadouts hit, I  uninstalled.\n\nFast forward to today, and it's one of the only multiplayer shooters I play. There's a one time 10 dollar purchase now, but you get full access for life. Even better, if you played it on steam before the switch, you get it free. Everything's been made sleeker, smoother, and that much easier to just pick up and play. That loadout thing everyone was complaining about? Only in a select few gamemodes. Make your own server, lobby up with friends, enjoy full steam integration, and above all, enjoy a classic game brought to the new age. Recommended for all shooter fans. One thing though: you're gonna get fragged. Hard.

reviewText:
Product received for free

About 2 hours prior to me posting this, I just found this game in my Seam Library, sense I spent my entire life on the free version about a year ago. I remember the game being really fun,  so I decided to go on ahead and download it and see if anything has changed...oh how my heart was broken.

First off, I would like to say that I have over 100 hours into this game back when I played it on a daily basis. Then I bought CS:GO and that kinda absorbed my life, but I digress. The point is I have a lot of experience on this game. What really caught my eye is that you have to now pay to play the game. After playing it for an hour or so I didn't really see any differences between the old free version and the now paid version. Another thing that caught my eye is that it now doesn't play on Mac or Linux, which really confused me. After I downloaded it and ran it, the UI was completely different and confused me, but afer a few minutes of going through the menu, I got used to it. I then went to the servers to find that this game is a completely desolate. Almost all of the servers had no people in it and the ones that did were packed. So after a some time of me searching for a server that I can actually join with people on it, I joined one. Once I joined in a freeze tag, everything basically seemed normal. The gameplay was the same and nothing seemed different other than voice chat.

In all honesty, this doesnt feel like a Pay to Play game. I've read multiple articles on why it was no longer FTP, and the only reason I could find was that now all players had the same benifits as the now dead subscribers, which were the map voting processes
date: having full access to customize their game to the same degree as others (which honestly I don't see the difference between customization then and now) and having the ability to run their own Listed Servers and configure their matches to their own liking." (Shaun Prescott on "Quake Live is no longer free-to-play") This doesn't feel like it's worth the 10 bucks and I strongly recommend you do not buy this game."

reviewText:
В «стимовском» Quake Live игрокам на выбор предоставлено более сотни арен, включая как новые официальные, так и наиболее интересные из числа созданных сообществом. Для любителей вести статистику предусмотрена возможность просмотра истории матчей, а также наблюдать за ростом своего «скилла».

Имеется более двенадцати игровых режимов, в числе которых настоящая классика жанра: все против всех, командный deathmatch, захват флага, доминирование. Не обойдётся и без эксклюзивных для Quake режимов. Разработчики также пообещали, что Steam-версия прямо в день релиза обзаведётся специальным обновлением, главной целью которого станет улучшение баланса и правка игрового процесса. Вероятнее всего, изменения коснутся сложности и механики игры в целом, поскольку слишком уж нишевым в своё время был продукт. Примечательно, что до той степени ураганности действий не может добраться, пожалуй, ни один современный шутер с заявкой на динамичность.
Конечно немного попортили баланс но один пряник играбельно ...

reviewText:
EDIT: QL is steamworks now and it has every benefit that platform provides. Also, every change I mentioned below can be turned off/on by voting before match or by server owner. Most negative reviews are based on removing game from limited free-to-play model (with monthly/yearly subscription for full game) to fixed price for full game, without subscriptions.
_______________________________________

The best adrenaline-pumping, fast-paced arena shooter. Basically, this is an updated version of famous Quake III Arena (released in 1999) which adds new game modes, maps and other content making the previous formula funnier then ever.

It is known that Q3A was hard to master, players needed a lot of practice in order to be competitive in online matches. Same thing is with QL, but this time, more attention has been paid to beginners:
- some nice tutorials with video demonstrations on mechanics (strafe and rocket jumping) and practice arenas are added
- online matches are a bit easier for beginners because different ammo clips for different weapons are replaced with universal ammo clips
- timer for armor and powerups is added, so every player will know when exactly they reappears on map
- starting loadout with one weapon (many negative reviews are based on this feature but I don't find it problematic).

These changes makes every player a more difficult opponent which wasn't a case with Q3A.

All in all, this game is definitely worth a try. Personaly, I learned my first FPS steps in Q3A and it helped me a lot in every FPS game I played. It will always be a #1 shooter for me.

reviewText: I've played Quake Live years before it was released on steam, and i need to admit the steam version takes some of the classic Quake feel to it due to the developers adding loadout options and even adding a heavy machine gun. Back in the older days this game was basically the same thing as Quake III Arena where you start off with the Machine gun and the gauntlet and then find all of the other weapons around the map. The game itself is still a lot of fun to this day, the combat gameplay is still the same as it was years ago, Just my only complaint goes to the loadout options where you can start off with an overpowered weapon and dominating all of the other opponents which makes the combat less of a challenge. My reason to that is back when you started off with the machine gun, the combat was more difficult when someone with the lightning gun would spawn kill you in the matter of seconds. With all of that being said, the game is still a whole lot of fun. I will recommend this game to the players who like free-for-all or CTF combat without the constant raging like in CoD(I'm not comparing this game to CoD). If you're a huge Quake fan like i am then you will be very confused at first with the game mechanics but the combat is still pretty much the same as in Quake III Arena.\n\nEdit: Feel free to add me, my username is tlp

reviewText:
What the F**k HappenedSummer 2014: Released terrible update that introduced auto-bhop, loadout system, altered gameplay balances, and other trash.
October 27, 2015: Released out-of-the-blue update that removes most of the garbage, gave everyone all the maps, allows anyone to make their own private servers, wiped stats and old friend lists.
Later that day on October 27, 2015: Suddenly made the game $10 on Steam, so anyone who didn't already have it installed when it downloaded said update now have to pay for it, regardless of how long they'd played the game or if they had a pre-existing PRO subscription or not.

Understandably, people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥. However, I didn't have to pay for it, and I never gave a rat's ♥♥♥ about the friends lists or stats (stats don't mean ♥♥♥♥ to me on any game besides being a milestone counter, and all my quake-playin friends can easily chat with me outside of Quake, so...) so this update didn't sting me nearly as hard as some of the other reviewers here.

What you get for the price is a whole lot of game. You get basically everything Q3A had besides the Campaign" mode
date: which was just a bunch of loosely-connected bot matches
recommended: which you can do on here anyway. You get it all basically for half the price Q3A goes for on here (which honestly
hoursPlayed: should've been $9.99 for a long time now anyway.) It's a good deal. The actual game itself is not trash-tier in any way

really.

reviewText:
So for some reason, this game used to be free to play but now is 10 dollars? I still have it in my steam library for some reason so I guess I'm lucky but seriously what the hell?! The entire point of having this free to play was to have people be able to play a version of quake 3 without needing to pay money for it, that's it. Seriously instead of wasting money on this just wait until a steam sale happens or something and play the original Quake 3 (for some reason they're asking 20 dollars for that one, makes no damn sense). Oh by the way, the Steam Workshop is just another way for them to get to paid mods or something and try and keep the already dead game alive. The irony of this is that, as of now, I can be 99% sure that the Quake 3 Arena has more players playing on their servers than Quake Live.  You know how many empty servers I saw when I opened this up (out of luck that it was still in my library even though I didn't spend money on it)? Don't answer that. We both know there's usually only a few active servers these days. If you want mods, a good solid non-shill like multiplayer game that has the word Quake within its name, and a much more active community just try literally any of the other Quake games. Not only that, but they all have Linux and Mac support (Linux support was removed some time ago). Don't bother with this. Dedicated servers and a dead modding scene isn't enough to make it 10 dollars.

JUST

FUG

MY

SHEET

UP

Free, fast paced pure action FPs fun. Get it. It's free.

9.5/10

reviewText:
This game is fun when you can find a server.  The matchmaking system is terrible.  It puts you into full servers, European servers, or empty servers the majority of the time.  Also, when you try to join a team deathmatch game, you're probably not going to end up in a team deathmatch game.

The people that play this game seem like they've never played a deathmatch game before.  It's not uncommon to win a deathmatch game with 50 frags and 2 or 3 deaths.  Finding players that are an actual challenge is extremely difficult.  It's no fun to just beat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ all day.

The game itself is fun, but the other players and servers kill the fun.

reviewText:
This game ROCKS! i've only played a little so far, this is my first online shooter, and it's good for newbies. it's completely free, and the training mode will help you become a Quake master.


First, this game has A LOT of features, and the customization is crisp. All you need is a couple of minutes to suit up and be ready for battle.

Second, the animation, no, the levels themselves, are surrealistic and amazing in style. Favorite level: Beyond Reality. Lots of thrills there.

Finally, the game is just a remake of a good classic. What more could you want? This may be only intended for Hardcore players, but if you're a newbie in the world of Online Shooters, this game will be a treat.

9.5/10
